value:
Traditional Hatari festival garb instills
courage in the wearer, and paints the
battlefield in a storm of glorious color.

Hatari culture thrives in part due to
our long isolation from the rest of
Tellius.

I can best any competitor with my
strength alone. I need not rely only
upon the power of the evil eye.

Ike and his group have no interest
in participating? Odd that they pass
up an opportunity to test their skills.

We ask only this of our competitors...
Believe in your strength. Fight until
you have nothing left to give!

You are hereby invited to the
Hatari festival by your good
friend $Nf.

The savage strikes of the wolf queen
will rattle your very bones!

Do not hold back on account of this
being a festival. Bare your fangs!

If this is not enough to lift our spirits,
then I shall double my efforts!

Give yourself over to the festival!
Let its frenzied atmosphere nourish
your soul!

I, Nailah, ruler of the desert kingdom
Hatari, look forward to seeing the
Askr people enjoy my land's festival.

The desert can be cruel. Everything
seems built to kill you. Still, such
adversity can be unifying.$k$pWhen you fight only to survive...
race, creed, and upbringing stop
having much meaning.$k$pStrong are ties forged in adversity. It
is for this reason that our festival is
focused so heavily on combat.$k$pWhen you bare your fangs, others see
that you are willing and ready to
defend what matters most to you.$k$pHave you taken the opportunity to
find a battle sister or brother during
the festival, $Nu?$k$pLet the festival's excitement awaken
your primal rage. Only then can you
learn the true limits of your strength!
たあっ
動くな
くっ…
これほどとは…
Welcome to Hatari.
To the wolves.
Bow.
Having fun?
How unbecoming...
ふう…
I am Nailah, Queen of Hatari. Welcome to my desert.
You are in my domain. I'd advise you to tread lightly.
Fighting to fight is a waste. This festival gives fighting a purpose.
My festival garb is much more comfortable than my formal attire.
Don't mind my companion. Rafiel is only here to spectate.
It's important to make time for a celebration every now and then.
What do you think of the festival? Give me an outsider's perspective.
As you say.
Where to?
We'll meet them head-on.
